item.title: Vsftpd: Setting up virtual hosts with MySQL
item.description:
Introduction link

vsFTPd, short for Very Secure FTP Daemon, is a free, simple, and secure FTP server.

It was developed with the best possible security in mind to address vulnerabilities in classic FTP servers.

item.title: Network Flows
item.description:
Introduction link

Network flows about network denial of service attacks is the subject addressed here. Indeed, network flows allow for very simple detection of distributed denial of service attacks due to the quantity of flows generated by the zombie army attacking you.

In this article, we’ll present other applications of these network flows: intrusion detection or policy violation, detection of hidden channels, or even worm proliferation to name just a few examples. While the detection of distributed denial of service is something relatively specific to operators and Internet service providers, are the other applications well suited to an internal network?

item.title: FTP: Automate Transfers
item.description:
Introduction link

It’s sometimes convenient to automate certain tasks like uploading files or other operations.

FTP link

With the universal ftp command, here’s an example that you can place in a shell script:

 transfertFile()
{
 inputFile=$1
 
 ftp -n <<end
 prompt
 open $Hostname $Port
 user $Login $Password
 ascii
 put $inputFile
 bye
end
}

item.title: AutoFS: Mounting and Unmounting Shares
item.description:
Introduction link

You already installed Linux on your networked desktop PC and now you want to work with files stored on some other PCs in your network. This is where autofs comes into play. This tutorial shows how to configure autofs to use CIFS to access Windows or Samba shares from Linux Desktop PCs. It also includes a tailored configuration file.
